Well, Andrew Jackson ran a foul of Congress, especially the Senate, when he vetoed a measure to renew the charter of the Bank of the United States.
This was a favorite of Henry Clay and the Whig Party.
And Henry Clay had hoped to make the Bank of the United States an issue in the 1832 presidential election, in which he was opposing Andrew Jackson.

He believed that the president could not withdraw the deposits on his own authority, that he needed to consult and get the agreement with Congress.
Jackson didn't think that was necessary.
He only thought was that as president this was one of his presidential prerogatives.
So Clay arranged for the Senate, which was at this point in the hands of anti-Jacksonians, the emerging Whig Party, to censure President Jackson.

This outraged Jackson, and in fact, it rallied the Democrats around Jackson in a way that they hadn't been able to.
It looked as though the Whigs, the anti-Jackson party, was probably going to win in the Congressional elections of 1834 and perhaps carry the White House in 1836.

But in large part, because of the censure resolution which rallied the Democrats around Jackson, which gave them an opportunity to campaign in 1834 and again in 1836 on the issue of Andrew Jackson, despite the fact that he wasn't on the ballot, and it allowed the Democrats to win in 1836 against all expectations.
